title: 114_s1944
content: The Act may be cited as the Regulations Endanger Democracy Act of 2015 or the RED Tape Act of 2015. Repeal of rules required before issuing or amending rule. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as "agency," "covered rule," and "rule," which includes rules issued by agencies in response to Executive orders or Presidential memoranda. The Unified Agenda of Federal Regulatory and Deregulatory Actions defines terms such as "agency" and "covered rule." An agency is prohibited from issuing a covered rule that does not amend an existing rule unless the cost of the new rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed. An agency is prohibited from issuing a covered rule that does not amend an existing rule unless the cost of the new rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed. Failure to comply results in no statutory pay adjustment until the agency rectifies the issue. An agency is prohibited from issuing a covered rule that does not amend an existing rule unless the cost of the new rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed. No statutory pay adjustment shall take effect for any employee of the agency in relation to the covered rule. The head of the agency must consider certain factors when deciding to repeal a covered rule. The head of the agency must consider factors like effectiveness, adverse effects, costs versus benefits, obsolescence, and overlap with other rules when deciding to repeal a covered rule. Each agency must submit covered rules to the Office of Unified Agenda semiannually. The agency must submit a list of rules to be issued, repealed, or amended in the next 6 months, along with their costs, to the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs. An agency cannot issue a rule without complying with these requirements.
